los.title: 01: Javascript Client Review

los.summary: jQuery: a library to facilitate and simplify access to the DOM

los.summary: Use both native JavaScript and JQuery to access and manipulate the DOM.

los.summary: Introduce Ajax via a JQuery example

los.summary: Explore the github API

los.title: 02: Introducing Node
los.summary: The fundmendals of node. Using node as a api client. A first node application.

los.title: APIs & Node
los.summary: APIs & Node

los.title: Node Context
los.summary: What is node? What is its role in modern development? We look at some key characteristics of the platform

los.title: FourSquare Service
los.summary: Review the FoureSquare Service + its API. Examine an endpoint from a number of perspectives

los.title: FourSquare API in Node
los.summary: Develop a JS Module to access the Foursquare API.

los.title: Lab 02a FoureSquare API
los.summary: Create developer account and explore the API using the browser.

los.title: Lab 02b FoureSquare JS
los.summary: Write a javascript program to retrieve FourseSquare venue information.

los.title: 02a: Introducing Node
los.summary: 02a: Introducing Node

los.title: Node Applications
los.summary: Introduction to node development, framing the origins of node and its role in modern applications. Explore some simple node code and identify its unique features

los.title: Node Components & Evolution
los.summary: A look at the components of node, its evolution and key advantages

los.title: Programming Node
los.summary: Examine synchronous and asynchronous programming in node

los.title: The Hapi Framework
los.summary: Introduce Hapi, positioning it within the spectrum for Node Frameworks. Identify Hapis' unique features.

los.title: Lab 02b Applications
los.summary: Create a new simple node/HAPI project to serve a simple set of static views.

los.title: 02b: Node Applications
los.summary: 02b: Node Applications

los.title: Node Sync/Async Examples
los.summary: Source project for the node sync/async examples discussed in the talk.

los.title: 03: Hapi Applications
los.summary: HAPI application structure: controllers, views & sessions.

los.title: 6: Views
los.summary: Explore the role of the HAPI application framework. Examine routing, connections, handlers and views within HAPI. Explore HAPI views in depthReview the DRY principle and the role of layouts. Employ the handlebars templating engine, incorporating partials and other constructs.

los.title: Hapi Building Blocks
los.summary: Enumerate the core building blocks of hapi and explain how these are assembled into a simple application.

los.title: Static Views
los.summary: Explore how to server simple views using the Hapi Inert plugin

los.title: Templates
los.summary: Extend the static view with more dynamic capabilities with the vision plugin and the handlebars templating engine.

los.title: Lab 03a Views
los.summary: Extend the application to employ layouts, templates, and partials. Include simple interaction features to track users and donations.

los.title: 03a: Views
los.summary: 03a: Views

los.title: 7: Sessions
los.summary: Review the role of Sessions in web applications. Incorporate the hapi-auth-cookie plugin into HAPI application to manage sessions. Review session strategies, protected and unprotected routes, cookie passwords, timeouts and other configuration options.

los.title: Free Code Camp
los.summary: Brief tour of the Free Code Camp curriculum

los.title: Sessions
los.summary: Sessions, via hidden form fields, url rewriting and cookies.

los.title: Sessions in Hapi
los.summary: The hapi-auth-cookie plugin provides cookie management for Hapi applications

los.title: Lab 03b Sessions
los.summary: Incorporate sessions tracking into the app, defining a session strategy, protected and unprotected routes and cookie paramaters.

los.title: 03b: Sessions
los.summary: 03b: Sessions

los.title: 04: Models
los.summary: Introducing NoSQL Databases, Mongodb characteristics & configuration. Using Mongoose Schema & Objects

los.title: Models I
los.summary: Introduce Persistence layer technology, specifically via a NoSQL databases. Explore the role of an ODM in this context and review the fundamental modeling techniques.

los.title: Introducing NoSql DBs
los.summary: A review of the NoSQL movement and some of its key characteristics

los.title: Setting Up Mongo
los.summary: Installing, connecting to and initialising Mongoose/MOngo db from a node application.

los.title: Accessing Mongo
los.summary: Creating and using Objects in Mongo, using its promise based API

los.title: Lab 04a Models I
los.summary: Replace the simple user and donation tracking with a database implementation - Mongo DB. Use the Mongoose ODM to create User + Donation models.

los.title: Models II
los.summary: Models II

los.title: Mopngo Methods & References
los.summary: Extending the basic schema to include references to other object + static & instance methods

los.title: Error Handling
los.summary: Using exception handling + an error partial to catch and report errors

los.title: Lab-04b Models II
los.summary: Extend the model is include Donations

los.title: 05: Seeding & Deployment
los.summary: Deployment to the cloud. Seeding the database.

los.title: Joi Validation
los.summary: Joi Validation

los.title: Joi Validation
los.summary: Joi is a node validation module providing general purpose schema based validation.

los.title: Hapi Validation with Joi
los.summary: Hapi & Joi can work together to deliver easy to configure declarative validation for handlers.

los.title: Lab 05a Validation
los.summary: Include an object relationship from donor to user, and render a donors full name on the report view. Incorporate validation into registration view.

los.title: Versioning & Deployment
los.summary: Versioning & Deployment

los.title: Semantic Versioning
los.summary: Version numbering in the node ecosystem

los.title: Node on Heroku
los.summary: Heroku is a PaaS, supporting node and a variety of other application types. We review here the steps involved in deploying a node app.

los.title: Lab 05b Deployment
los.summary: Deploy the application + the mongo database, to an application server.

los.title: Model Seeding
los.summary: As models increase in complexity, seeding the database with an object graph is a useful technique, enhancing developer productivity. It facilitates exploratory development + early validation of model decisions.

los.title: Relationships between Mongo Documents
los.summary: Creating and maintaining relatopnships between mongo documents enable powerful models to be constructed and queried.

los.title: Mongoose Seeding
los.summary: Seeding the database can simplify exploratory development, prepopulating the database with simple test data during development.

los.title: Candidate Model
los.summary: Users should be able to donate to different candidates. We extend the model to include Candidates, incorporating candidate references into donations.

los.title: Lab 05c Seeding
los.summary: Include a mongoose seeder component in the application. Use this to validate a new Candidate model, preloading it with a json specified object graph.

los.summary: Setting the scene

los.summary: Use a cryptographic application to manage keys and carry out encryption and authentication exercises

los.title: APIs
los.summary: Exposing a programmatic interface to a service can facilitate more diverse client. These can include test clients to exercises the application, a mobile application or alternative front ends.

los.title: APIs
los.summary: An Application Programmer Interface is the published set of http endpoints and messages that a service can support. API design and implementation is a rich field of study - here we take a general overview.

los.title: Endpoints
los.summary: Expose access to the Candidates model as a REST endpoint. This involved defining new routes and handlers, which respond simple JSON representations.

los.title: Testing Endpoints
los.summary: Tools like Postman and Insomnia usefully exercise endpoints. However, we can also exercise them problematically, which offers some significant advantages.

los.title: Lab 06b Apis
los.summary: Start the development of an API for the donation service, focusing initially on providing access to the Candidates model. Implement the API using simple REST principles.
